newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: FOCUS - VNU says Blenheim strategic buy.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - VNU says Blenheim strategic buy.

text.p: Dutch publisher VNU said on Tuesday its acquisition of a 14.99 percent stake in Britain's Blenheim Group was a strategic long-term investment.
"A significant investment in such an exhibitions business is...in line with our long-term strategy of expanding in professional information markets," VNU chairman Bart Brentjens said in a statement.
Exhibitions and conference organising currently account for a scant one percent of VNU group turnover.
Subsidiaries active in this segment are Bill Communications of the U.S. and VNU Business Publications in Britain.
VNU announced earlier it had bought a 14.99 percent stake in Blenheim from institutional investors at a price of 500 pence per Blenheim share.
It said it was not weighing a short-term bid for all Blenheim shares outstanding, barring rival offers for the firm.
"The acquisition of this stake fits with our strategy to expand our spread of activities in other types of media and other geographical areas," VNU spokesman Maarten Schikker said.
Blenheim was a highly internationally-oriented company with attractive gross margins, he added.
The exhibitions organisor had a significant presence in France, the United States, Britain and Germany, covering 14 different market sectors. Its gross margin in 1995 was 21 percent, Schikker said.
Schikker declined to comment on how far VNU was prepared to build up its newly-acquired stake in Blenheim or whether it planned eventually to take over the company completely.
"That's a difficult question to answer at this moment. We will consider our position in the near future," he said.
VNU's bid for Blenheim shares represents a premium on their Monday closing price of 435-1/2 pence.
"We think this is a full price," Schikker conceded, adding "we are prepared to pay five pounds ($7.8) (per share) to secure a long-term holding in Blenheim. It is a fair price."
"We believe this a very good deal," he added.
-- Lien van der Leij, Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000 ($ = 0.640 British Pounds)
